[[Buddhism]] sets [[Upādāna|attachment]] and [[Taṇhā|desire]] as negative emotions that release [[anger]] and cause suffering; love and [[ego]] are incompatible. In the buddhist philosophy, true love is compassionate love.<ref name="Buddha">[http://books.google.es/books?id=VECepVHTH0QC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Guatama Buddha. ''The Dhammapada''. Translated by Irving Babbitt.]</ref> [[Jesus Christ]] also embraces love from an [[altruism|atruistic]] and compassionate view ("love your neighbor as yourself"). [[Gottfried Leibniz]] believes that if one really understands and seeks love, he will always take pleasure in the happiness of another.<ref>[http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/journal_of_the_history_of_philosophy/summary/v015/15.3den_uyl.html The Aristocratic Principle in the Political Philosophy of Leibniz]. DJ Den Uyl - Journal of the History of Philosophy, 2008 - muse.jhu.edu.</ref>
 
[[Buddhism]] sets [[Upādāna|attachment]] and [[Taṇhā|desire]] as negative emotions that release [[anger]] and cause suffering; love and [[ego]] are incompatible. In the buddhist philosophy, true love is compassionate love.<ref name="Buddha">[http://books.google.es/books?id=VECepVHTH0QC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false Guatama Buddha. ''The Dhammapada''. Translated by Irving Babbitt.]</ref> [[Jesus Christ]] also embraces love from an [[altruism|atruistic]] and compassionate view ("love your neighbor as yourself"). [[Gottfried Leibniz]] believes that if one really understands and seeks love, he will always take pleasure in the happiness of another.<ref>[http://muse.jhu.edu/journals/journal_of_the_history_of_philosophy/summary/v015/15.3den_uyl.html The Aristocratic Principle in the Political Philosophy of Leibniz]. DJ Den Uyl - Journal of the History of Philosophy, 2008 - muse.jhu.edu.</ref>
 
 
−
[[Sigmund Freud]] thinks that unconditional love from a mother leads to perpetual dissatisfaction: "When you were incontestably the favorite child of your mother, you keep during your lifetime this victor feeling, you keep feeling sure of success, which in reality seldom doesn’t fulfill". He describes love as a [[narcissism|narcissistic]] behavior; human beings only love what they were, what they are, what they want to be.
+
On the other side, [[Sigmund Freud]] thinks that unconditional love from a mother leads to perpetual dissatisfaction: "When you were incontestably the favorite child of your mother, you keep during your lifetime this victor feeling, you keep feeling sure of success, which in reality seldom doesn’t fulfill". He describes love as a [[narcissism|narcissistic]] behavior; human beings only love what they were, what they are, what they want to be.
 
 
 
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem in humanistic psychology|self-esteem]] as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relationship, including interpersonal love. [[Abraham Maslow]] places love at the ''love/belonging level'', between the ''safety level'' and the ''esteem level'', in his [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|hierarchy of needs]].
 
[[Humanistic psychology]] sets healthy [[self-esteem in humanistic psychology|self-esteem]] as an essential requirement for every healthy interpersonal relationship, including interpersonal love. [[Abraham Maslow]] places love at the ''love/belonging level'', between the ''safety level'' and the ''esteem level'', in his [[Maslow's hierarchy of needs|hierarchy of needs]].
